Robert Watkins wrote:

> Firstly, if you've got factories for your domain objects, you can verify 
> that your factories are used correctly, via coding conventions and 
> analysis tools (e.g. checkstyle). Testing your factories is pretty 
> simply, as a general rule. In general, factories tend to be safer to use 
> than constructors, anyway, so you actually gain from the factories.

None of which prevents somebody from writing their own implementation of 
the interface, instantiating it and bypassing the factories completely.

> Secondly, you can't rely on objects to define behaviour in stone, 
> anyway. Maybe someone came along and removed that pesky "final" keyword 
> (either directly or via bytecode engineering). Or perhaps they've simply 
> swapped the class out with another one that matches the same interface. 
> In short, you can only rely on "final" to lock down behaviour if you're 
> the only one writing the source code.


The source (or byte) code can always be forked. At that point it's out 
of my hands, and not really my responsibility. But they can't just swap 
out my class for a different one, if I've written the implementation to 
depend on classes rather than interfaces. That's pretty much the point.

> Thirdly, interfaces define contracts. Implementations which do not 
> conform to the contracts aren't socially responsible - you shouldn't 
> build them that way. How do you make sure you build them right? Testing, 
> peer reviews, and well-defined types.

All good ideas, but if this were sufficient we never would have needed 
access protection in the first place.

> Finally: the very fact that you can change the implementation randomly 
> is a benefit, not a problem. In particular, unit test code gains from 
> being able to provide an arbitrary implementation of an interface that 
> it just can't do with a class.

In other words, you can write an implementation that passes the test 
even if the real implementation doesn't. How does that help?

> It sounds like you've got some fairly serious trust issues about the 
> competence and/or integrity of the developers you work with, if you're 
> trying to lock down their behaviour that tightly. Is that a fair assessment?

The developers I work with are everyone who downloads my code. Some of 
them I trust. Some of them I don't. They range in skill levels from 
extremely experienced, wise, knowledgeable developers like Michael Kay 
to random undergraduates and unreconstructed COBOL hacks. However one 
thing they all have in common is that they're using my code because they 
implicitly or explicitly trust me and my library(s). I promise that the 
library behaves in a certain way under certain conditions and 
accomplishes certain tasks. I can do this only because my libraries are 
designed around concrete classes. Were the library designed around 
interfaces instead, I could no no longer make such promises. Even my own 
code that I trust could be compromised were someone to inject a 
misbehaving implementation they themselves had written. Few classes 
operate in isolation. I code my FOO class under the assumption that the 
BAR class behaves in a certain way. If someone replaces the BAR class 
with a misbehaving version, then not just BAR but also FOO and 
everything else that depends on it could be compromised.
